qas.question: What are compounds that have a carbon-copper bond called?
What does organocopper compounds reactions toward oxygen form?
What is produced when copper compounds are treated with organolithium reagents?
Coupling products can be made by substituting Gilman reagent with what?
Which form of copper is shock sensitive?
What are compounds that have a black-copper bond called?
What does organocopper compounds reactions toward water form?
What is destroyed when copper compounds are treated with organolithium reagents?
Which form of copper is time sensitive?

context: Compounds that contain a carbon-copper bond are known as <a0_0><b5_0>organocopper compounds<b5_0/><a0_0/>. They are very reactive towards oxygen to form <a1_0><b6_0>copper(I) oxide<b6_0/><a1_0/> and have many uses in chemistry. They are synthesized by treating copper(I) compounds with Grignard reagents, terminal alkynes or organolithium reagents; in particular, the last reaction described produces a <a2_0><b7_0>Gilman reagent<b7_0/><a2_0/>. These can undergo substitution with <a3_0>alkyl halides<a3_0/> to form coupling products; as such, they are important in the field of organic synthesis. <a4_0><b8_0>Copper(I) acetylide<b8_0/><a4_0/> is highly shock-sensitive but is an intermediate in reactions such as the Cadiot-Chodkiewicz coupling and the Sonogashira coupling. Conjugate addition to enones and carbocupration of alkynes can also be achieved with organocopper compounds. Copper(I) forms a variety of weak complexes with alkenes and carbon monoxide, especially in the presence of amine ligands.
